chunks.episode_title: Why laughter is the best medicine
chunks.chunk_text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.To find out more, visit our website.

chunks.episode_title: Why laughter is the best medicine
chunks.chunk_text: Well, I'm glad you're laughing because, as we'll be finding out in this programme, laughter is good for you. In fact, laughter is often called the best medicine.And it seems that's really true, medically speaking.

chunks.episode_title: Why laughter is the best medicine
chunks.chunk_text: But before we start tickling our funny bones, I have a quiz question for you, Neil, and it's no laughing matter. Laughter can be a serious business.In fact, there's a scientific field of study into laughter and its effects on the human body.But what is this study called?Is it a...

chunks.episode_title: Why laughter is the best medicine
chunks.chunk_text: Did you make those words up, Sam?They sound a bit funny to me.I'll say the study of laughter is called... OK, Neil, but you'll be laughing on the other side of your face if you're wrong.Anyway, we'll find out the correct answer later in the programme.

chunks.episode_title: Why laughter is the best medicine
chunks.chunk_text: We'll have Edmunds, presenter of BBC World Service programme The Big Idea, exactly how a laugh is produced.

chunks.episode_title: Why laughter is the best medicine
chunks.chunk_text: The haha sound you make when you laugh comes from your rib cage, a structure made of bones, called ribs, in your chest which protects the heart and lungs.The rib cage works like a drum to amplify a laugh.It's the reason why jokes are sometimes called rib ticklers.Professor Scott calls this a very primitive way of making sounds because it's simple, natural and essentially human.The word primitive

chunks.episode_title: Why laughter is the best medicine
chunks.chunk_text: can be used to describe anything relating to the basic way humans lived at their early stages of development, before money, machines or writing were invented.Primitive human noises like crying and laughing link to a universal human experience.And this can be seen in the large number of words we use to talk about them.In English, chuckle, giggle, chortle, cackle and guffaw all describe different types of laughter.

chunks.episode_title: Why laughter is the best medicine
chunks.chunk_text: Can you describe a giggle, Sam?I'd say a giggle is laughing in a quiet but uncontrolled way, like a child who finds something very funny or feels embarrassed.Unlike a guffaw, which is when you blast out a very loud laugh, often at something stupid or rude someone has said.But humans aren't the only animals to laugh.We belong to the same family as other primates like chimpanzees, gorillas and orangutans, all of whom laugh.

chunks.episode_title: Why laughter is the best medicine
chunks.chunk_text: Professor Scott says laughter is an

chunks.episode_title: Why laughter is the best medicine
chunks.chunk_text: element which give birth to live young, rather than laying eggs, and who feed their young with milk.By laughing, young mammals, sometimes called juveniles, signal that they want to play, and young rats, who don't laugh back, are more likely to get a bite than a giggle.And a rat bite is nothing to laugh about.What a lot of facts we've learnt about laughter, Neil.Yes, we could almost be experts on laughter.Guffologists, isn't that what you called them, Sam?Ah, yes.In my quiz question,

chunks.episode_title: Why laughter is the best medicine
chunks.chunk_text: I asked you to name the scientific study of laughter and its effects on the body.I'm almost certain it's not giggleology or guffology, so the answer must be...Gelatology, the correct answer. Well done, Neil. I knew you were good for a laugh.OK, let's recap the vocabulary from the programme before you think up any more terrible jokes.

chunks.episode_title: Why laughter is the best medicine
chunks.chunk_text: And finally, a young animal which is not fully grown can be called a juvenile.

chunks.episode_title: Why laughter is the best medicine
chunks.chunk_text: 6 minutes are up.Join us again soon for more trending topics, useful vocabulary, and who knows, maybe some terrible jokes, here at 6 Minute English. Bye for now.Goodbye.
